Los Filtros Filter Plant is located at road #833, Km 14.8 Bo. Los Filtros, Guaynabo, Puerto Rico, 00965. This water treatment plant is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct & Sewer Authority (PRASA) wich is a Government Agency.PRASA  has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for management and prevention of risks associated with the storage and use of chlorine, a regulated toxic substance, at the Los Filtros Water Filtration Plant.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 and Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112®(1).  The Prevention Program elements build upon the facility's Process Safety Management (PSM) system prepared in compliance with 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is PRASA's policy to comply with applicable Federal and State requirements.  The disinfection process at  Los Filtros Water Filtration Plant uses chlorine, a hazardous toxic substance regulated by EPA, OSHA, and PROSHO.  Due to the hazardous characteristics of chlorine, the Los Filtros Water Filtration Plant observes various safety precautions in the storage, conveyance and use of chlorine.  The safety precautions are necessary to protect employees, contractors, and visitors at the Los Filtros Water Filtration Plant and the immediately surrounding areas.  Safety precautions include procedures and equipment to minimize the potential for accidental release, as well as a written emergency response program for response to any chlorine release that may occur.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Los Filtros Water Filtration Plant supplies  water to the surrounding community.  Chlorine is used to disinfect the water, destroying microorganisms that could cause illness in humans.



Chlorine is delivered  from the Puerto Nuevo Distribution Center to the plant in 1 ton containers by truck. Chlorine containers are connected to valves and through them the chlorine flows  to 8 vacuum chlorinators.  From the chlorina

tors the dosified chlorine flows to the ejectors then the chlorine solution is applied through to different injection points (5) in the process of the plant.



Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios



The worst-case release scenario was determined following EPA's Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F, Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants. This guidance considers the release of the cholrine gas of an  entire container (2000 Pounds) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the  weather conditions and a radius of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene association exposure limit wich is determine human health will be affected.                                                                                                                                                                           

Alternative case Scenario. The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant parameters, as a release of the total content of a container, but throughtout a pipe leak. In the case the end point distance is calculated at 0.1 miles and some public receptors are identified over the most recent maps. .                                                                                       

General Accidental Release Prevention Program                                                                                                                     

PRASA is actually in a very agrgressive operation to implement a Prvention Plan to ensure the maintenace and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of current prevention plans. Different Standard Operational Procedures (SOP) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine. List of all  SOP are indicated in

the PSM report and are located in the plant. 



Emergency Response Program



PRASA has various SOPs to manage emergency associated to a chlorine release and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events. 



Five-year Accident History



With the past five years there have been no unplanned release of chlorine in excess of 10 pounds resulting in injuries or significant property damage on site; or known offsite injuries evaluations sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



PRASA has already implemented in the Los Filtros Filtration Plant, an alarm system and automatic valve mechanism to improve the control of the process and the safety of the chlorine handling and storage. It is recommended to replace the chlorine feeder device from a high preassure system to a low preassure system (vacuum).  



Audits



The last compliance audit was conducted on october 22, 2010. But during the past two years we have conducted internal metrics evaluations. With each internal metrics evaluations; we request an action plan to correct the findings. PRASA has develop these evaluation to establish the level of compliance of our facilities with the RMP/PSM Program.
